title: Armine Wodehouse (Liberal politician)
text:
Armine Wodehouse (24 September 1860 – 1 May 1901) was a British civil servant and <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28UK%29">Liberal</a> politician.
Biography.
Wodehouse was a younger son of <a href="John%20Wodehouse%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Kimberley">John Wodehouse, 1st Earl of Kimberley</a>, and his wife Lady Florence, daughter of Richard FitzGibbon, 3rd Earl of Clare. He was assistant private secretary to his father, as <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20the%20Colonies">Colonial Secretary</a> 1880–82 and as <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20India">India Secretary</a> 1882–85, then principal private secretary when Lord Kimberley was India Secretary again in 1886 and 1892–94, and <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Foreign%20and%20Commonwealth%20Affairs">Foreign Secretary</a> 1894–95. After <a href="Archibald%20Primrose%2C%205th%20Earl%20of%20Rosebery">Lord Rosebery</a>'s government, including Kimberley, resigned in June 1895, Wodehouse was appointed a for his service in the Foreign Office. 
In the subsequent <a href="1895%20United%20Kingdom%20general%20election">general election</a> he stood for Parliament unsuccessfully in the <a href="Isle%20of%20Wight%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Isle of Wight</a>. 
In October 1900 he was returned to Parliament for <a href="Saffron%20Walden%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Saffron Walden</a>. Considered one of the more promising young Liberals in the <a href="British%20House%20of%20Commons">House of Commons</a>, he only held the seat until his early death in May the following year.
Wodehouse married Eleanor Mary Caroline, daughter of the author <a href="Matthew%20Arnold">Matthew Arnold</a>, in 1889. They had one son. Wodehouse died in May 1901, aged only 40. His widow later married <a href="William%20Mansfield%2C%201st%20Viscount%20Sandhurst">William Mansfield, 1st Viscount Sandhurst</a>. She died in December 1934.
